questiontext.text:
Engineering Example: Currents in two loops

In the circuit shown below find the currents \((i_1,\ i_2)\) in the loops:

Figure 1


Solution

We note that the current across the \(3\ \Omega\) resistor (travelling top to bottom in the diagram) is given by \((i_1-i_2)\). With this proviso we can apply Kirchhoffâ€™s law: \[\begin{matrix} \text{In the left-hand loop} & 3(i_1-i_2)+5i_1=3 & \rightarrow & 8i_1-3i_2=3 \\ \text{In the right-hand loop} & 3(i_2-i_1)+6i_2=4 & \rightarrow & -3i_1+9i_2=4 \\ \end{matrix}\]

In matrix form: \[\left[ \begin{matrix} 8 & -3\\ -3 & 9 \\ \end{matrix} \right] \left[ \begin{matrix} i_1 \\ i_2 \\ \end{matrix} \right]= \left[\begin{matrix} 3 \\ 4 \\ \end{matrix} \right].\]

The inverse of \[\left[\begin{matrix}\hfill 8& -3 \\ -3& 9\end{matrix}\right]\] is \[\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right]\] so solving gives \[\left[\begin{matrix}i_1\\ i_2\end{matrix}\right]=\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}9&3\\3&8\end{matrix}\right] \left[\begin{matrix}3\\ 4\end{matrix}\right] =\dfrac{1}{63}\left[\begin{matrix}39\\ 41\end{matrix}\right]\] so \(\displaystyle{i_1= \frac{39}{63}}\), \(\displaystyle{i_2= \frac{41}{63}}\).
